question:
Who among the following was the first principal of the Bengal National College started in 1906 ?

SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Morning)
solution:
• Aurobindo Ghose (also spelled Sri Aurobindo) was appointed as the first principal of the Bengal National College in 1906.
  • The college was established as part of the Swadeshi Movement, following the Partition of Bengal (1905), to promote national education free from British control.
  • The aim was to provide Indian-oriented education with an emphasis on patriotism, science, and self-reliance.
  • Aurobindo Ghose, a noted scholar and nationalist, played a crucial role in shaping the intellectual and political discourse through this institution.

Additional Information:

  • The college later became part of the Jadavpur University system.
  • Aurobindo Ghose resigned in 1907 to fully dedicate himself to the freedom struggle and revolutionary activities.

question:
When was the All Bengal Students Conference held in the chairmanship of Jawaharlal Nehru?

SSC MTS 01/10/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The All Bengal Students Conference was held under the chairmanship of Jawaharlal Nehru in the year 1928.
  • This event was part of the growing political awareness and participation of students in the national movement during the late 1920s.
  • Nehru, as a rising national leader, addressed the youth, emphasizing the importance of nationalism, self-reliance, and the need to oppose colonial rule.
  • The conference played a role in mobilizing student activism in Bengal, which became a significant force in the Indian freedom struggle.

Additional Information:

  • The conference helped in forming student unions and spreading anti-imperialist ideas among the youth.
  • Such student movements laid the foundation for future revolutionary activities, especially in Bengal.

question:
In 1927, where was the conference against colonial oppression and imperialism, in which Jawaharlal Nehru participated on behalf of Indian National Congress, held?

SSC MTS 29/10/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• In 1927, Jawaharlal Nehru attended the International Congress against Colonial Oppression and Imperialism held in Brussels, Belgium.
  • He represented the Indian National Congress at this global platform, which brought together leaders and thinkers opposing colonialism and imperial rule.
  • The conference aimed to promote solidarity among oppressed nations and discussed strategies to combat imperialism worldwide.
  • This participation helped Nehru form international connections and reinforced his commitment to anti-imperialist and socialist ideals.

Additional Information:

  • The Brussels Congress was organized by the League against Imperialism, which later included revolutionary and anti-colonial activists from Asia, Africa, and Latin America.
  • It marked a significant moment in the globalization of India’s freedom struggle and Nehru's rising role as an international voice for decolonization.

question:
What is the year of foundation of the Women’s Indian Association (WIA)?

SSC MTS 04/11/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Women’s Indian Association (WIA) was founded in the year 1917 in Madras (now Chennai).
  • It was one of the earliest women’s organizations in India focused on women’s rights, education, and social reform.
  • The association was founded by Annie Besant, Margaret Cousins, and Dorothy Jinarajadasa.
  • WIA played a major role in promoting women’s suffrage (voting rights) and worked to improve the status of women under colonial rule.

Additional Information:

  • The WIA also raised its voice on issues like child marriage, women’s education, and healthcare.
  • It was affiliated with international women’s movements and represented Indian women at global forums.

question:
Which of the following national leaders of India inaugurated the first Akhil Bhartiya Kalidas Samman Samaroh held in Ujjain in 1958?

SSC MTS 11/11/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The first Akhil Bhartiya Kalidas Samman Samaroh was held in 1958 in Ujjain, Madhya Pradesh, a city closely associated with the ancient poet and dramatist Kalidasa.
  • This event was inaugurated by Dr. Rajendra Prasad, the first President of independent India.
  • The Kalidas Samaroh was initiated to honour classical Indian literature, especially Sanskrit, and to celebrate the legacy of Kalidasa, one of India’s greatest poets.
  • The event brought together scholars, poets, and artists from across the country.

Additional Information:

  • Ujjain, being a historic and cultural center, is traditionally considered the birthplace or workplace of Kalidasa.
  • The Kalidas Samman later evolved into a prestigious award for excellence in the fields of classical literature, arts, and culture.

question:
Who became the Nawab of Bengal after the death of Alivardi Khan in the year 1756?

SSC MTS 12/11/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• After the death of Alivardi Khan in 1756, his grandson Siraj-ud-Daulah became the Nawab of Bengal.
  • Siraj-ud-Daulah was the last independent Nawab before the Battle of Plassey (1757), which led to the establishment of British control in Bengal.
  • His rule faced internal dissent and conspiracies from powerful court officials like Mir Jafar, Jagat Seth, and others.
  • The conflict between Siraj-ud-Daulah and the British East India Company, particularly over the misuse of trade privileges, led to the Plassey battle.

Additional Information:

  • The Battle of Plassey was fought on 23 June 1757, where Siraj-ud-Daulah was defeated due to the betrayal by Mir Jafar.
  • This defeat marked the beginning of British political dominance in India.

question:
On which of the following dates did the British Empire transfer its powers to the Constituent Assembly in India?

SSC MTS 13/11/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The British Empire officially transferred power to the Constituent Assembly of India on 15th August 1947.
  • On this date, India became an independent dominion, and the Constituent Assembly began functioning as the sovereign legislative body of the nation.
  • Although the Constitution of India came into effect later on 26th January 1950, the real transfer of political authority from British to Indian hands happened on 15 August 1947.
  • This marked the end of British colonial rule after nearly 200 years.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Mountbatten was the last Viceroy of British India and became the first Governor-General of independent India.
  • Jawaharlal Nehru delivered the famous “Tryst with Destiny” speech on the night of 14–15 August 1947.

question:
Who among the following has authored the play ‘Nil Darpan’ ?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The play ‘Nil Darpan’ was authored by Dinabandhu Mitra in 1860.
  • It is a Bengali drama that portrays the exploitation of indigo farmers (nilakars) by British planters in colonial Bengal.
  • The play is based on the Indigo Rebellion (1859–60), where Indian peasants protested against the forced cultivation of indigo.
  • ‘Nil Darpan’ is considered a pioneering work in Indian protest literature and played a major role in mobilizing public opinion against colonial injustice.

Additional Information:

  • The English translation of the play by Michael Madhusudan Dutt and published by Reverend James Long led to a libel suit by the British.
  • The play is regarded as a catalyst in the rise of Indian nationalism through literature.

question:
Who among the following freedom fighters of India is the author of the book, 'The Indian Struggle’ ?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The book "The Indian Struggle" was authored by Subhas Chandra Bose.
  • It was written during his stay in Europe between 1934 and 1935, and published in 1935 in London.
  • The book covers the history of India’s independence movement from 1920 to 1934, focusing on both Gandhian movements and revolutionary politics.
  • It also presents Bose’s views on Indian nationalism, the future of India, and his criticism of British colonial policies.

Additional Information:

  • The book was banned by the British government in India at the time of its publication due to its anti-imperialist content.
  • Bose’s ideas in the book reflect his inclination towards militant nationalism and his vision for a free and strong India.

question:
Which of the following books is INCORRECTLY paired with its respective author?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Hind Swaraj– Mahatma Gandhi
option_3: The Discovery of India– Subhash Chandra Bose
option_4: Why I am an Atheist– Bhagat Singh
solution:
• (a) Hind Swaraj – Mahatma Gandhi → Correct

    Gandhi wrote Hind Swaraj in 1909, outlining his philosophy of Swaraj (self-rule), non-violence, and critique of modern civilization.

  • (b) Gitanjali – Rabindranath Tagore → Correct

    Tagore authored Gitanjali, a collection of poems, which won him the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1913.

  • (c) The Discovery of India – Subhash Chandra Bose → Incorrect

    The Discovery of India was written by Jawaharlal Nehru, not Subhash Chandra Bose, during his imprisonment in 1944 at Ahmednagar Fort.

  • (d) Why I am an Atheist – Bhagat Singh → Correct

    Bhagat Singh wrote Why I am an Atheist in 1930 while in jail, defending his rationalist and atheistic beliefs.

Additional Information:

  • Subhas Chandra Bose authored books like The Indian Struggle (1935).
  • The Discovery of India is a key text for understanding Nehru’s vision of Indian history and unity.

question:
Match the following institutes with their respective founders of British India.

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)

Institutes

Their Respective Founders

a. Asiatic Society of Bengal

Warren Hastings

b. Sanskrit College of Benaras

Lord Wellesley

c. Fort William College

Jonathan Duncan

d. Calcutta Madrasa

Sir William Jones
option_1: a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
option_2: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
option_3: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
option_4: a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
solution:
Let's match the institutes with their correct founders:

  • a. Asiatic Society of Bengal → Sir William Jones

    Founded in 1784, the society was established by Sir William Jones, a scholar and jurist, to promote Oriental studies.

  • b. Sanskrit College of Benaras → Jonathan Duncan

    Established in 1791 by Jonathan Duncan, then Resident of Benares, to promote the study of Hindu law and philosophy.

  • c. Fort William College → Lord Wellesley

    Founded in 1800 by Lord Wellesley, the college was set up in Calcutta to train British civil servants in Indian languages and culture.

  • d. Calcutta Madrasa → Warren Hastings

    Established in 1781 by Warren Hastings, it was one of the earliest Islamic educational institutions under British patronage.

Correct Match:

  • a → iv (Sir William Jones)
  • b → iii (Jonathan Duncan)
  • c → ii (Lord Wellesley)
  • d → i (Warren Hastings)

Answer: (c) a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i

question:
In which of the following areas did the Uprising of Khurda in 1817 take place?

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Khurda Uprising of 1817 took place in the region of Odisha.
  • It was one of the earliest armed uprisings against British rule after the fall of the Khurda kingdom, whose ruler Raja Mukund Dev II was dispossessed in 1804.
  • The 1817 revolt was led by Jagabandhu Bidyadhar, also known as Buxi Jagabandhu, who rallied the Paika warriors (military class) and local peasants.
  • This rebellion is also known as the Paika Rebellion of 1817, and it opposed British land revenue policies and administrative changes.

Additional Information:

  • The uprising is considered by many as a precursor to the Revolt of 1857.
  • In recent years, there have been efforts to recognize the Paika Rebellion as the first war of Indian independence.

question:
Where was the Hindu College established in the year 1791?

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Hindu College was established in the year 1791 at Benaras (now Varanasi).
  • It was founded by Jonathan Duncan, the then Resident of Benaras, with the aim of promoting Sanskrit education and the study of Hindu law and philosophy.
  • The institution later came to be known as the Sanskrit College, and it played a key role in the preservation and revival of Indian classical learning during colonial rule.

Additional Information:

  • Hindu College in Calcutta (Kolkata) was founded later in 1817, which is a different institution altogether.
  • The Benaras Hindu College is one of the earliest educational initiatives by the British for traditional Indian learning.

question:
In 1936, The Independent Labour Party was founded by _______.

SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Independent Labour Party (ILP) was founded by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar in 1936.
  • It was established as a political platform to represent the interests of the Depressed Classes (Dalits) and working-class people.
  • The ILP focused on labour rights, social justice, and the eradication of caste discrimination.
  • The party contested the 1937 provincial elections under the Government of India Act 1935 and won 15 seats in the Bombay Legislative Assembly.
  • ILP later merged into the Scheduled Castes Federation (SCF) in 1942.

Additional Information:

  • Dr. B. R. Ambedkar is known as the principal architect of the Indian Constitution.
  • He was the first Law Minister of Independent India and a staunch advocate of social equality and Dalit upliftment.
  • The ILP was an early step towards mobilizing the depressed classes through political participation.

question:
When was the All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) established?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) was established in the year 1920.
  • It is the oldest trade union federation in India and played a key role in organizing workers against colonial exploitation.
  • The founding session was held in Bombay (now Mumbai) on 31 October 1920.
  • Prominent leaders like Lala Lajpat Rai (first president), Joseph Baptista, and N. M. Joshi were involved in its formation.
  • AITUC was associated with the Indian National Movement and later became aligned with leftist ideologies.

Additional Information:

  • AITUC later became affiliated with the Communist Party of India (CPI).
  • It was instrumental in leading several worker strikes and labour rights movements across colonial and post-colonial India.
  • Its formation marked the beginning of organized labour activism in the country.

question:
Who founded the Theosophical Society in New York in 1875?

SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Naoroji Furdunji and Satyendra Nath Bose
option_2: Baba Dayal Das and Madan Lal
option_3: Ramabai Ranade and GK Devadhar
option_4: Madame HP Blavatsky and Colonel Olcott
solution:
• The Theosophical Society was founded in New York in the year 1875.
  • Its founders were Madame Helena Petrovna Blavatsky and Colonel Henry Steel Olcott.
  • The society aimed to promote universal brotherhood, study comparative religion, and explore mysticism and occult sciences.
  • In 1879, the founders moved the society’s base to India, establishing its headquarters at Adyar, Madras (now Chennai).
  • The society played a significant role in India's cultural and spiritual revival in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

Additional Information:

  • Annie Besant, a British social reformer, later became a prominent leader of the Theosophical Society in India.
  • The society also supported Indian nationalism and educational reforms, including the establishment of Central Hindu College (which later became part of BHU).
  • The Theosophical Society’s motto was: “There is no religion higher than Truth.”

question:
What gave a major impetus to the cotton textile industry in India after Independence?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Partition of India in 1947
option_2: Export of raw cotton to England
option_4: Development of railway network
solution:
• The Swadeshi Movement gave a major impetus to the cotton textile industry in India.
  • Though it began during the freedom struggle (1905 onwards), its ideals continued post-Independence, encouraging the use of indigenous goods.
  • It promoted self-reliance and boycott of foreign cloth, increasing demand for Indian-made textiles.
  • After Independence, this mindset encouraged investment and expansion of textile mills to meet local needs and reduce imports.
  • The cotton textile industry grew rapidly in places like Mumbai, Ahmedabad, and Coimbatore, aligning with the national policy of industrial self-sufficiency.

Additional Information:

  • Partition of 1947 had mixed effects: many cotton-growing areas remained in India, but key mills were also in Pakistan.
  • Export to England actually declined post-Independence as India moved towards self-use.
  • Railways did aid transport but were not the primary factor for growth post-1947.

question:
________ is one of the first criticism of the caste system written by Mahatma Phule and published in the year 1873.

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (2nd shift)
option_2: Bharat Mein Jaati Evam Prajaati
solution:
• "Gulamgiri" (meaning "Slavery") is a pioneering work written by Mahatma Jyotirao Phule in 1873.
  • It is one of the earliest and strongest critiques of the caste system and Brahminical dominance in India.
  • In this book, Phule compares the condition of lower castes in India to that of slaves in America, showing the deep-rooted social injustice and inequality.
  • "Gulamgiri" laid the foundation for anti-caste thought and Dalit assertion in modern India.
  • The book was dedicated to the American abolitionists who fought against slavery, drawing a global parallel.

Additional Information:

  • Mahatma Phule also founded the Satyashodhak Samaj in 1873 to fight caste oppression and promote education among the oppressed classes.
  • He is regarded as one of the pioneers of social reform in India, particularly in the field of education, women's rights, and caste justice.

question:
In his ‘Drain of Wealth’ argument, who among the following stated that Britain was completely draining India?

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The concept of the "Drain of Wealth" was prominently propagated by Dadabhai Naoroji.
  • He argued that Britain was draining India’s wealth through economic exploitation during colonial rule.
  • Naoroji presented this theory in his book “Poverty and Un-British Rule in India”, published in 1901.
  • He highlighted how India’s wealth was being transferred to Britain through trade imbalance, salaries of British officials, home charges, and interest payments on loans.
  • This economic critique laid the foundation for economic nationalism in the Indian freedom struggle.

Additional Information:

  • Dadabhai Naoroji is known as the Grand Old Man of India.
  • He was the first Indian to become a Member of the British Parliament.
  • He was also one of the founders of the Indian National Congress (INC).

question:
Who is the author of the Indian national anthem?

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The author of the Indian National Anthem, “Jana Gana Mana”, is Rabindranath Tagore.
  • It was originally composed in Bengali in 1911 and later adopted as the national anthem of India on 24 January 1950.
  • The original song was written in Sanskritized Bengali and set to music by Tagore himself.
  • The first public performance took place at the Calcutta Session of the Indian National Congress in 1911.
  • Only the first stanza of the full composition was adopted as the national anthem.

Additional Information:

  • Rabindranath Tagore was the first Asian to win the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1913.
  • He also composed the national anthem of Bangladesh – Amar Shonar Bangla.
  • Tagore was a polymath – poet, philosopher, painter, and educationist.

question:
Which Commission drew the boundary line between India and Pakistan?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Radcliffe Boundary Commission was responsible for drawing the boundary line between India and Pakistan in 1947.
  • It was headed by Sir Cyril Radcliffe, a British lawyer who had never been to India before.
  • The commission was created to demarcate the borders of Punjab and Bengal based on religious majority (Hindus and Muslims).
  • The award, known as the Radcliffe Line, was announced on 17 August 1947, two days after India’s independence.
  • This demarcation led to large-scale migration and communal violence during the partition.

Additional Information:

  • The Radcliffe Line became the international boundary between India and Pakistan.
  • The decision was taken under the Mountbatten Plan (June 3, 1947) which facilitated partition.
  • The line later also defined the boundary between India and East Pakistan (now Bangladesh).

question:
Which British colonel is remembered as the Butcher of Amritsar for his role in the Jallianwala Bagh massacre in 1919 ?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• The British officer known as the "Butcher of Amritsar" is Colonel Reginald Dyer.
  • He was responsible for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre that took place on 13 April 1919 in Amritsar, Punjab.
  • On that day, Dyer ordered his troops to fire without warning on a peaceful gathering of unarmed civilians, killing hundreds and injuring over a thousand.
  • The massacre was a response to protests against the Rowlatt Act, which allowed detention without trial.
  • Dyer’s actions were widely condemned in India and even criticized in Britain, though some supported him at the time.

Additional Information:

  • The massacre deeply shocked the Indian public and became a turning point in India’s freedom struggle.
  • It led to Rabindranath Tagore renouncing his knighthood as a mark of protest.
  • The incident is considered one of the darkest chapters in British colonial rule in India.

question:
Vasco da Gama, who discovered the sea route from Europe to India, belonged to which nation?

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• Vasco da Gama was a Portuguese explorer who is credited with discovering the sea route from Europe to India.
  • He landed at Calicut (now Kozhikode), Kerala on 20 May 1498, marking the beginning of European colonial interests in India.
  • His voyage was significant as it established direct maritime trade between Europe and Asia, bypassing overland routes dominated by Arab and Persian traders.
  • This event marked the start of Portuguese colonial expansion in the Indian Ocean region.

Additional Information:

  • Vasco da Gama’s voyage was sponsored by King Manuel I of Portugal.
  • He made three voyages to India, and on his third journey, he was appointed the Portuguese Viceroy in India.
  • The success of his journey led to the establishment of Portuguese trading posts and later colonies in India, particularly in Goa.

question:
Tattvabodhini Patrika promoted the study of India’s past in which language?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Tattvabodhini Patrika was a prominent journal started in 1843 by Debendranath Tagore, a key leader of the Brahmo Samaj.
  • The journal was published in Bengali and aimed to revive and promote the philosophical and cultural heritage of ancient India.
  • It played a crucial role in encouraging the Bengali intelligentsia to study Indian scriptures, Upanishads, and Vedic philosophy.
  • The Patrika became a mouthpiece of the Tattvabodhini Sabha, which was closely linked to the Brahmo Samaj movement.

Additional Information:

  • The journal also promoted rational thinking, reformist ideas, and modern education.
  • It contributed significantly to the Bengal Renaissance, a period of cultural, social, and intellectual awakening in 19th-century Bengal.
  • Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar and Keshab Chandra Sen were influenced by such reformist literature.

question:
Who among the following stated in 1902, India was not ruled for its benefit, but rather for the benefit of its conquerors?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• In 1902, Annie Besant remarked that India was not ruled for its own benefit, but for the benefit of its conquerors.
  • This statement was a critique of British colonial rule, highlighting how the administration in India primarily served imperial interests rather than the welfare of Indians.
  • Annie Besant, though of British origin, became a strong advocate for Indian self-rule and social reforms.
  • She was deeply involved with the Theosophical Society and later led the Home Rule Movement in India.

Additional Information:

  • Annie Besant founded the Home Rule League in 1916, demanding self-governance for India within the British Empire.
  • She also served as the first woman President of the Indian National Congress in 1917.
  • Her efforts significantly influenced Indian nationalism and inspired many Indian leaders.

question:
Sanskrit College at Benaras was founded by ________.

Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The Sanskrit College at Benaras (now Varanasi) was founded by Jonathan Duncan in 1791.
  • Duncan was the British Resident at Benares, and he established the college to promote the study of Hindu scriptures, philosophy, and law.
  • The college aimed to train Hindu pandits in traditional texts, especially Sanskrit literature, Vedas, and Dharma Shastra.
  • It became one of the earliest institutions for Orientalist education in India during the British colonial period.

Additional Information:

  • Jonathan Duncan was a supporter of orientalist policies, which encouraged the promotion of Indian languages and culture.
  • Later, the college played a key role in the preservation and promotion of Sanskrit and classical Indian learning.
  • The institution is now known as Sampurnanand Sanskrit University.

question:
Who designed India Gate, also called the All-India War Memorial?

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The India Gate, also known as the All-India War Memorial, was designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens.
  • It was built to honor the 70,000 Indian soldiers of the British Indian Army who died during World War I (1914–1918).
  • The memorial stands in New Delhi and was completed in 1931.
  • Lutyens was a prominent British architect and also played a key role in the design and layout of New Delhi, the new capital of British India.

Additional Information:

  • The names of more than 13,000 soldiers are inscribed on the India Gate.
  • In 1971, the Amar Jawan Jyoti was added beneath it to commemorate Indian soldiers who died in the Indo-Pak war.
  • Edwin Lutyens is also known for designing the Viceroy’s House, now Rashtrapati Bhavan.

question:
Who was the political guru of Subhash Chandra Bose?

SSC MTS 05/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• Chittaranjan Das was the political guru of Subhash Chandra Bose.
  • Subhash considered him his mentor and guide during the early phase of his political career.
  • Bose worked closely with Das in the Swaraj Party, which was formed in 1923 to enter legislative councils and oppose British policies from within.
  • Das played a major role in shaping Bose’s nationalist and radical outlook, especially in Bengal politics.

Additional Information:

  • Chittaranjan Das was popularly known as Deshbandhu (Friend of the Nation).
  • He was a prominent lawyer, freedom fighter, and mayor of Calcutta.
  • Bose once referred to Das as “the man who discovered me”, showing the deep influence Das had on him.

question:
The name of the Brahmin priest who later came to be known as Ramakrishna Paramahansa is:

SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The original name of Ramakrishna Paramahansa was Gadadhar Chattopadhyaya.
  • He was born in 1836 in Kamarpukur, West Bengal, into a Brahmin family.
  • He became a priest at the Dakshineswar Kali Temple, where he experienced profound spiritual visions and mystical states.
  • Over time, he came to be known as Ramakrishna Paramahansa, revered for his teachings on universal religion, devotion (bhakti), and spiritual unity.

Additional Information:

  • His most famous disciple was Swami Vivekananda, who spread his teachings across the world.
  • Ramakrishna emphasized the harmony of all religions, saying that all paths lead to the same truth.
  • The Ramakrishna Mission, established by Swami Vivekananda in 1897, is based on his ideals.

question:
When did the Drafting Committee publish the first draft of the Indian Constitution?

SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Drafting Committee of the Indian Constituent Assembly published the first draft of the Indian Constitution in February 1948.
  • The Drafting Committee was chaired by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar, and it was formed on 29 August 1947.
  • After extensive deliberations, the first draft was prepared and circulated among members and the public for feedback in February 1948.
  • The final draft was submitted to the Constituent Assembly on 4 November 1948, and the Constitution was adopted on 26 November 1949.

Additional Information:

  • The Indian Constitution came into full effect on 26 January 1950.
  • The Drafting Committee had 7 members, and Dr. Ambedkar played the key role as the chief architect.
  • Public suggestions and criticisms were considered before finalizing the Constitution.
